text: Yeah, so my involvement with cosmos started, as many of these things do with the open source project tendermint. So I met jay back in, I think, late 2013, maybe early, the co founder of cosmos, the creator of tendermint, and he had this I was just getting into cryptocurrency. Everyone was talking about proof of work, proof of stake was like kind of a thing like, dan. Wermer was talking about it for EOS. But Jay had what seemed like the best ideas of basically anyone I met in cryptocurrency. He was like, we're going to have blockchains. We can combine what we have learned from why Bitcoin works and why it's great, and combined it with all this academic research that has been sitting on the shelf for decades and no one has found a constructive use for we could put it all together and turn it into something. And so I started contributing in various ways to the Tendermint project. And then we held a conference at our office. There was something called the Crypto Economic Research Group, which was this mailing list back in the day. And we held a conference for that mailing list. And people like Vlad and Vitalik all came to this conference. And I invited Jay because he was my friend and he presented Tendermint. And honestly, I remember seeing Vitalik's eyes light up a lot when he saw what Jay was doing and being, oh, like, this is a good know. Ethereum is now proof of, you know, back, uh, and then Ethan was friends with Vlad from college and had been contributing to early Ethereum, like the early Geth implementations. And so Ethan came to the conference. Jay and Ethan met. That kind of was like the first major full time contributor now to Tendermint was Ethan. They co founded the company. So it really started to become a sort of actual thing. But then they tried to do enterprise blockchains because that's what everybody was doing in 2015 and failed miserably. And then in 2016, they were like, we're going to do a public blockchain. And there were a series of ideas. Jay had this idea called White J. And Jahan, who was his roommate housemate, had this idea called Supertanker, which looks awfully like what Celestia does today. There were a whole bunch of iterations of ideas and eventually we came to what we now know as Cosmos. So my involvement with the project just kept increasing. 2016, I put the first, what is the first person to agree to put money into the project. By 2018, I was like full time on the project and then 2019, and then we had sort of the famous explosion of Tendermint in early 2020. And now I've kind of gotten much more sucked back into Cosmos core. So here we are.

text: All right, so now let's get into the nitty gritty on Cosmos. But we're going to start with a super basic question just to make sure all the listeners are on the same page. Why don't you guys explain what Cosmos is and also what application specific blockchains are?
speaker: A

text: Okay, I'll take the first shot at this. So, Cosmos. What is cosmos? Cosmos has been described as an idea, not a thing. So there's this big idea, which is blockchains are a kind of new kind of computer, a community computer that a computer that can be quite controlled and owned by multiple people. It's like an extension of, like, first we had the mainframe computing revolution, then the personal computing revolution, and now we have the community computing revolution. And this is what we've been trying to like, this is sort of where Cosmos is. And if you're going to have community computers, they should be able to network together. So that's like the Galaxy Brain version of the idea. The little bit more nitty gritty is Cosmos is a toolkit for building, like, an L one blockchain. So, like many blockchains that people know about until it blew up, the most famous one was the Terra Luna blockchain, the Cosmos Hub, Osmosis, Axelar. Many, many other blockchains that I'm sure listeners are familiar with are built with a set of tools. The tools are the tendermint consensus engine, the Cosmos SDK. And then if you build with those two things, you can bridge or connect or interoperate with any other blockchain in this ecosystem using a protocol called IBC. And so this has been a set of tools. Now, why did we build these tools? At the time of 2016, we saw smart contracts were starting to take off on Ethereum. But we had this deep belief that in the long run, the most successful blockchain applications would not be smart contracts. They would be like, blockchains themselves. The biggest, most successful, most important blockchain applications would end up being their own blockchains. And that was like in a sort of somewhat inevitable progression. And so what we needed to build was tools for people who may or may not have been building smart contracts at the time when they were ready and they kind of knew what they wanted from their application to build that application specific blockchain. So on most other blockchains, a Dex is a smart contract. In Cosmos, a Dex is a blockchain where the logic of decentralized exchange is built into the core blockchain protocol, lending protocols, et cetera. We have application specific blockchains for all of these things.
speaker: B

text: And maybe this would be a question for Jack, but when an entrepreneur is kind of trying to figure out how it is that they want to build whatever decentralized thing that they want to build, what are you seeing? In terms of kind of their thought process around choosing to, yes, build something more akin to a smart contract on a layer one like ethereum versus making an app specific blockchain on Cosmos. Kind of who goes with the first and who goes with the know, one.

text: Of the sort of classes of blockchain that Cosmos has done a great job of capturing is all of the exchange chains. If you look back to web two and think about things like Farmville and a lot of these other Facebook games that got sort of rugged by platform changes, the same thing can happen in blockchains, know, whether it's an upgrade to the underlying Ethereum network that changes the way you're making money. Know, there's a huge NFT mint that spikes fees and suddenly your app is unusable for long periods of time. That's a risk that a lot of application developers don't want to take, and those folks kind of end up choosing their own blockchain. But there's also folks like dYdX who have built their stuff as a smart contract on another chain initially and then sort of seen some of these effects and then they sort of move over to an independent chain. But the general theme there is sort of sovereignty and sort of controlling your own platform. And that is really attractive to a wide spectrum of developers.

Or what would you say there?

text: I think it's kind of a quick to launch thing too. It's very easy to write a smart contract, throw it up, generate an easy front end off of it, and start selling product to users. And a lot of startups and apps want to do that. If you look back at sort of traditional computing, you've got serverless platforms and infrastructure as a service, stuff like GCP and AWS, and then people can kind of run their own data center and that's kind of like a continuum. If you think about blockchains, there's smart contracts, there's run your own validator set and there's kind of a bunch of stuff in between like Celestia and shared security on the hub. Yeah, it's just kind of different entrepreneurs, different startups have different requirements and they sort of fall somewhere on that spectrum.

text: And so for people that say that aptains are not very composable, what would your response be to that?
speaker: A

text: Triathmosis go for it. Tucky.
speaker: C

text: The sort of more concrete answer is I kind of view that there's a trade offs. When you started out, there were like the first few people to try to build Cosmos chains and this is before IBC people tried to build them and they really struggled with network effects. Like they struggled to get listed on exchanges, how to onboard users. They needed to get a new user, had to get new wallets. It was a whole nightmare for users. And so if you launched on an Ethereum or a Solana, you kind of got all those network effects for free and you launched on Cosmos you didn't. And what we have seen over the sort of intervening timeframe is the differentiation between the network effects you have access to by launching on top of Cosmos and the network effects you have access to by launching on top of an established smart contract platform, getting smaller and smaller. And then Composability is one of those network effects. Can your system financially be composed with other systems? And one of the whole points or what are the views of Cosmos is that the Internet was built out of Asynchronous Composability. Most financial systems operate on asynchronous composability. Asynchronous composability? There's no reason why we cannot build a global financial system out of Asynchronous Composability. And so what you are starting to see is just like more and more interesting ways of composing things using IBC, where transferring tokens from one blockchain to another was what the email was to the Internet. The transferring tokens is to inter blockchain stuff. And we're starting to see much more sophisticated ways of composing blockchains starting to happen now.
speaker: B

text: And like Sommelier is a great example of that. The Sommelier chain controls and runs a set of smart contracts over on Ethereum and is able to send Ethereum transactions directly from the validator set of the Sommelier chain. That's a great example of asynchronous composability in production today. The toolkit that IBC enables is just a lot more expressive. And in terms of the primitives for building that kind of asynchronous composability offers much, much more than pretty much all other bridges out. You know, what we're in the middle of seeing right now is the development of a bunch of new IBC protocols, interchange accounts, interchange queries, the ability to read and write to other blockchains that can then be used in sort of cool and unexpected ways. And we're starting to see the first set of those applications now.
speaker: C

text: Yeah, I would say that in general, it feels like Cosmos is at an inflection point. Obviously, it's been generating a lot of good buzz, a lot of activity. Surprisingly, or maybe not surprisingly, it hasn't suffered too much from the collapse of Terra, even though, as like you mentioned, it was a Cosmos chain. And at the recent Cosmoverse conference, you did reveal a revamped white paper. So what was the impetus for that? What problems did Cosmos have that the community was trying to address?
speaker: A

text: So we have this thing we call the Cosmos Hub white paper. So the framing for this was in 2016, we wrote a white paper. Ethan and Jay wrote a white paper about this vision of the Cosmos network. And in that white paper, almost nothing is mentioned about the Atom token, the Cosmos Hub, any of these things. Like, it was like, we envisioned this network, we envisioned this use case, we envisioned proof of stake. And so we're going to yeet into the world a prototype of all of these ideas that runs on a token called a thing called the Cosmos Hub. And that is going to be the product. And for the people who participate in the community, that was going to be like the coordination point of the shelling point. And we finished that white paper in 2021. It's done everything that was in the white paper exists in the world. We completed the work. And so one of the things, though, that has so as the network has grown and expanded, we have about 50 IBC connected blockchains now in the network. The atom token and the cosmos hub has seemed directionless. There has not been a clear vision of what it was. We've started to conceive of features that should be added to the Cosmos Hub. So there's this new concept called interchange security, which actually uses IBC to expand the number of blockchains that a single proof of stake token can secure. It's sort of this form of shared security that we are building for the Cosmos Hub. But there's still no vision for the Atom Token. And this lack of vision, I feel like, is really holding back our ecosystem. Adam is a widely available, widely listed token. But like Tarun's joke about Adam is, it's dogecoin for academics. And I think that there is some truth to this in its current form. So here we were, we had this amazing, truly amazing community created conference. Again, Cosmoverse is not sponsored by a foundation or a dev company or anything. It is primarily sponsored by the blockchains themselves. So, like the Cosmos Hub Community Fund, the community treasury of everything, and we go to that conference and in coordination with our organizers, we did present a new vision that we call the Cosmos Hub White Paper, or more colloquially, Atom 2.0. But in Cosmos, no one, no individual entity has remotely the power to make such a big change to the software or to the blockchain. And Cosmos is not like a cult of Zucky or Jack or anyone else. And so we are now in the midst of this community driven process of evaluating that vision, discussing that vision. There's going to be an on chain governance vote about that vision in about two weeks. But even regardless of how that vote goes, we've started down a multi year process. But if our goal was to reinvigorate the subcommunity, reinvigorate thinking about what Adam could be, change people's perspectives, I feel like we've already accomplished that with the White Paper and with the presentation. So I'm very happy about all that.
speaker: B

text: All right, so let's unpack some of the ideas that you guys proposed in there. Let's start with the security aspect. I'm sure most people who have heard of this, the interchange security proposal, it really seems very similar to Polkadot, where multiple chains can share security. And I was wondering, why is it that this was the direction that you felt Cosmos Hub should go?
speaker: A

text: This is an idea that was around even when the original Cosmos White Paper came out. When I came on in early 2018, the developers were saying, well, we shouldn't build IBC first, we should maybe build interchange security for the Cosmos Hub first. And this is an old idea. And it was why it was kind of the first Atom 2.0 idea to get worked on is because it had broad acceptance within the Atom community as something that we should do. One of the common sort of criticisms of the appchain model is that the security is much lower because each chain has to bootstrap their own validator set and they're responsible for their own economic security. So that we should have a way to sell the security of the most secure, validator set in the interchange to other chains. And when we were talking earlier about that sort of, like, spectrum of sovereignty, this falls somewhere in the middle. And that's a really active market right now. And there's a lot of compelling offerings. And I think that what we built with interchange security v One is definitely one of the most compelling offerings out there.
speaker: C

text: And I was curious. We talked about how with Ethereum, there are different smart contracts competing for block space. And so if this model goes through and you have different blockchains that are relying on Adam and the Cosmos hub for security, would that ever cause some sort of congestion on the network that would increase fees, know, kind of enable activity on one chain to affect another?
speaker: A

text: So the short answer is, like, what are the big concerns in this sort of blockchain innovation? Thing? Is one, is your blockchain halting? There's a lot of solana, gets a lot of criticism because of these downtimes that they periodically have. One of the things that we are very proud of and could not have been anticipated when we started is that the Cosmos Club has actually never had an unplanned halt since we launched in 2019. And I remember talking to our PR people when we launched and being like, they're like, what is the chances the blockchain is going to halt? And I'm like about 50%. And they're like, that's not great. And here we are. It's three years later. The blockchain has never halted. But we wanted to find a way of extending the functionality of the atom ecosystem without creating the competitive pressure that many blockchains face. It where they're like, we have to keep adding features that constantly increases risk. The whole vision of Cosmos is fault isolation. So what we did is we create each one of the interchange secure chains are in most ways an independent blockchain, which means that activity on them does not affect activity on any other chain. And we can take more risk on interchange secured chains, but we can also isolate been one of the things that was announced simultaneously at Converge and Cosmoverse is that USDC is coming to Cosmos as a consumer chain, which is what we call these interchange secure chains. And a big part of that appeal to circle and to center was, hey, we can provide an environment, a generalized asset issuance chain that has a very low attack surface area and is going to need to probably not going to need to be touched or upgraded or changed in any big way on a regular basis. And so the rest of the interchange security ecosystem can constantly evolve. We can build all these new things, the scheduler, the allocator. We can take a lot more risk. And they'll know that their USDC chain is just trucking along, secured by the economic value of atom and doing what it is that needs to do without really having with a lot of isolation from the rest of the ecosystem.
speaker: B

text: Okay, so essentially, block space on each of the chains does not affect block space on any of the others. They're just sharing the security. Would any activity on one chain affect fees on another?
speaker: A

text: No.
speaker: B

text: Okay.
speaker: A

text: The only way they would affect it is the fees from the consumer chains go to the staked atom holders as a way to sort of pay for that security.
speaker: C

text: A big theme of atom 2.0, just to kind of holistically, look at this is a lot of blockchains, when they build their staking token, are like, where is the sustainability of the staking token going to come from? And they're like, fees are where the sustainability of the staking token are going to come from. And cosmos has always basically been like, if fees are high, your blockchain has failed. Right? Fees should never be a meaningful source of revenue. Your blockchain has failed. If fees are like, they're there to prevent spam, they're not there to generate revenue. And so a big part of what we've Tried To do with Atom 2.0 and as we get into the other parts of it, the whole point has been to design a system that is like, no, you want to provide the most valuable service to users, which is the incremental cost should be as low as possible to just keep the systems from being overwhelmed by spam and bots and transactions that have low economic value. But you want to capture as much economically valuable transaction activity within your blockchain ecosystem as possible. So fees should be as low as possible, but then how do we make the thing sustainable? And this is what the puzzle that Adam 2.0 has been trying to solve. Okay?
speaker: B

text: And out of curiosity, if this proposal gets adopted, what percentage of blockchains do you expect that cosmos hub will end up securing?
speaker: A

text: It doesn't matter what the percentage is. It matters what the economic value is.
speaker: B

text: It matters what the economic what is.
speaker: A

text: Like, what the economic value of so a big part of the cosmos hub thesis is the cosmos hub value accrual thesis is that if you look at a value flow in cosmos, someone raises money for a new blockchain or a new entity. Someone goes and wants to buy something on osmosis or another dex, somebody wants to open a position on dYdX. The whole point of atom 2.0 sort of success model is if we can make the atom zone, the chain secured by atom, a part of as many of those sort of value flows as possible, there's a lot of opportunity for value to then accrue to atom. And that's sort of our goal. We're not trying to exclude any of the innovation around sovereign zones at all or impede them or compete with them. What we're trying to do is provide a set of essential building blocks that make sure that atom is relevant to the most important and largest value flows in cosmos.
speaker: B

text: And this kind of gets to the underlying design philosophy of Cosmos. We built a suite of open source tools that are free for anyone to use that enable you to launch your own blockchain and allow it to communicate with a bunch of other blockchains. Every other blockchain ecosystem has tried to build in multiple value capture points. In each one of those things. And our strategy has been basically open source that and then try to monetize on top of this. This is kind of a classic open source strategy. It's been tried in a number of sort of traditional fields. The one that always comes to mind for me is Kubernetes with Google where they sort of, like, won the container wars by building the best one and making it free. And then they tried to build monetization on top of that with their cloud platform. And that's kind of what we're doing with Atom 20. We built all these free to use open source rails. There's all this activity that's being generated, but none of it is accruing to the Cosmos hub. So how do we capture value in that world?

speaker: A

text: So let's talk about this whole the Cosmos Hub white paper proposes three new things that primarily don't exist in the cosmos Hub right now. So one is the treasury, which I believe is what you are referring to. The second piece is the scheduler and the third piece is the allocator. So this idea of the treasury is so if you look at the Cosmos Hub many other blockchains in the blockchain ecosystem they have sort of large on chain reservoirs of tokens that are designed for funding ecosystem activity. But the treasury is actually a much more developed thing than these underdeveloped sort of just like pots of money that are floating around in the various chains. So what we imagine the Cosmos Hub will do with its treasury is we actually think that there's a very small thing will be like funding dev work. So sure, there has to be money for both continued contribution from the Cosmos Hub to tendermint Cosmos SDK, IBC development of new consumer chains, et cetera. But one of the larger things is we just want the Cosmos Hub to be more like an economic actor. We want it to be like, hey, you have built this service liquid staking a new stablecoin backed by atom other economically useful things in the Cosmos ecosystem. A new token that is being distributed to atom stakers as an interchange secured zone. As people build these things, go out collectively as the Cosmos Hub and go out there and make investments, own LP shares, own assets, bootstrap, liquidity, do these things that only centralized things do now in the blockchain ecosystem, do it as a decentralized entity. So that's a big part of the treasury vision. And then the way in which the treasury rather than being continuously sort of draining the value from atom stakers to fund this activity. The idea is the treasury becomes a self sustaining thing because of two things. One is this idea of capturing mev value, sort of maximum extractable value, block production value through the scheduler and those funds flowing back into the treasury. And then also there's this idea of the allocator which is sort of a little bit of a collective investment fund but basically the profits from that feed back into the treasury. And so we go through this phase of this transitionary phase over the next three years as described in the white paper. And then what we've done is we bootstrapped the treasury. And at that point the treasury is supposed to sort of be generating ongoing self sustaining value for the atom community.
speaker: B

text: And just one note on the sort of like investing in other chains a really common pattern during the sort of bootstrapping of IVC is if you were launching a new token or a new zone in Cosmos, you would AirDrop your tokens to the atom token distribution. That's a really heavy handed way of sort of incentive aligning the atom community with whatever you're doing. And it's not a really long term way to do it because those users will often go dump those tokens. It's not really beneficial for everyone in the way that people really want it to be. What they want to do is they want the atom distribution, the atom holders themselves to make an investment in their chain and sort of have this sort of mutual economic benefit. And this is what the Interchange allocators is designed to do. It's designed to sort of formalize these relationships between these different blockchains on chain and enable the atom stakers to participate in the long term growth of the IBC ecosystem from an investment perspective.

text: And this is what is called covenants in the white paper.

text: So you've been mentioning the interchange scheduler, and it's essentially this cross chain marketplace for maximal extractable value. It's basically the flash spots of Cosmos, as far as I can tell. And I was curious, you mentioned that that value would then go into the treasury that's being extracted. As I'm sure you're aware, mev is a little controversial because there's what some people consider toxic forms of it, like front running and then other kinds that are helpful and make things more efficient. So I was curious, how will the interchange scheduler handle those different types of mev? Will it not seek to capitalize on what people consider toxic mev, or will it just go ahead and extract that as well?
speaker: A

text: Okay, so I'll start with a little higher idea before I answer the question, which is one of the big things that Tendermint has been working on is this thing we call ABCI Plus Plus, which is these improvements to Tendermint that make it easier for application specific blockchain developers to build in mev mitigations into their application. And I think one of the reasons why Cosmos has been so compelling, especially for DeFi builders to build on top of Cosmos, is that in other application specific blockchain ecosystems that are out there, the answer to what do we do about mev? Is like, no one's really ever thought about this. And in Cosmos, it's like we've been thinking about it for years. We have a plan. We built most of it. And this is a big part of the story, and we don't want to even in this world where the scheduler exists, we're not taking away the capacity of an application specific blockchain to mitigate toxic mev within their application. And it's like a huge reason why you build application specific blockchains. The actual biggest source of mev I don't know, it's the truth that people don't want to talk about is the actual biggest source of mev is between the exchanges and the blockchains. That is the actual biggest source of mev. As far as I can tell, it's not really being extracted yet. But exchanges know when you go click the exit button from an exchange, they're going to know they may be able to buy. What were you looking at in Coin Gecko right when you clicked exit on your exchange? They're going to have a lot of insight just from customer profiling about what financial actions are likely to come from that exit on the exchange. And at some point, exchanges are going to start front running this and that is the source of value that Adam holders. I think when we designed Adam 2.0, this is what the vision is really about, is like if we don't have a block space futures market, we're leaking all of that value back to the exchanges and atom holders have an opportunity to get a cut of it. And that might be a very valuable source of revenue that exceeds what you could ever earn from fees, for instance.

text: This will inevitably happen.

text: Okay, but I don't think it's it's.

text: Yeah, okay, I take your point. You're right that it is a possibility. One other thing I wanted to ask about, this know, flashpods is having this auction. It's on Ethereum, where, as we discussed, it's a very different model. And I was curious how efficient you thought a blockspace auction could be across app chains as it would need to be on Cosmos.
speaker: A

text: So the blockspace futures market, basically what this is, is an auction for blockspace across many different chains that are all connected to the Cosmos hub. And that auction happens via IBC. This kind of fundamentally gets down to the latency in IBC, and it requires one message on the sending chain and then another message on the sending chain on the receiving chain. So it's sort of the sum of the block times of the different chains. Right now, the Cosmos hub has, like, six second blocks. Evmos is running with two second blocks, and there's kind of nothing really preventing all the cosmos chains from doing that. Say network has done a lot of research into latency within tendermint, and their sort of beta net is running with, I think, 250 millisecond or 600 millisecond blocks. So definitely subsecond blocks. But if you've got, let's say, 1 second blocks, then your sort of IBC transaction time is 2 seconds. That's sort of a very long time. When we look at things like traditional ad markets with these huge sort of multivariate auctions that happen, we can absolutely provide good latency for this. And one of the other use cases for this sort of crosschain mev, which is definitely what the scheduler is designed to capture, is the Cosmos Hub will be selling block space on many, many different app chains simultaneously. And if you want something to happen over here at the same time it happens over there, this is going to be pretty much the only way to negotiate that with any sort of guarantees. And there's a lot of opportunity in that space as well.
speaker: C

text: All right, so now let's dive a little bit more into the crypto economics of Atom 2.0. Why don't you just describe what it is that was proposed here in terms of the changes to Issuance and et cetera?
speaker: A

text: Okay, so first statement about Issuance is, there's a proposal about changes to issuance. Whether or not this proposal is going to be the proposal that's actually implemented is the community process. And I doubt really just, like saying this, I mean, every blockchain founder is like, it's not me, it's the community. Literally, no one has this power to actually change anything like this. And it's going to be a public political process that's been playing out on Twitter and the Cosmos forum. There's probably never been so many posts on the Cosmos forum as there ever been. This is, again, like a community process. But the current dynamics of atom are this exponential infinite inflation, which is basically transferring values from non stakers to stakers. So people who have atoms out in DFI using atoms in the IBC economy are constantly transferring value back to the staking atom holders. At this point, the issuance rate for atoms is 9%, approximately. And it's dynamic based on how many people are staking in this model. But this is about a 20% yield. So you're like two xing, essentially. How much value is almost two xing? How much value is flowing from non stakers to stakers? And basically, what we propose in the Cosmos Hub white paper is that this is an unsustainable model. It's harmful to the ecosystem because it makes atoms a bad asset to use in IBC DeFi because of this continuous value extraction from people who are out there using it. And we want to profoundly change this model. And so basically, the idea is, first we create a bunch of new atoms that go into the treasury. We can get into it. We create a bunch of new atoms. They flow into the treasury. They don't go to any users. They're sexually collectively owned by the Cosmos Hub mechanism. No one the ICF, Jack and Zucky, no one's control of these atoms. It's still the property of the Cosmos hub. But then after three years, we very rapidly decrease the amount of inflation and we end up with an issuance rate that is about 1% and is steady state, not exponential, not adaptive, and we basically say the mature, stable state. So now Adam goes from this asset with a very unpredictable future supply that is going to something that becomes very predictable, very regular. And the big idea of this massive Mint into the treasury is we actually think that the best possible mean from Adam is how credible that total number of atoms that are out there in the universe is. And if we think if we were like, we sort of overshoot maybe like two or three X, like, what we actually think it will take to set up the economic flywheel, we end up with a lot of credibility to the market that there won't actually ever need to be another big issuance like this ever again.
speaker: B

text: Okay, so essentially right now, it's sort of this focus on it's sort of almost in a way, like a venture model where you're just giving it some capital in the beginning to help it grow to a certain point. And then once you reach that threshold, then you reach the steady state that you mentioned. Is that the idea?
speaker: A

text: Okay, I just wanted to take a brief digression at the beginning of that, zach, he was talking a little bit about Cosmos governance and how no one has control. I think that this is really one of the defining features of Cosmos. For a large number of historical one, there is no one entity in control of the project. Various folks at different times have tried to sort of exert control over the project, and that has not worked out well. And if you go look on Mintscan and look at the recent governance proposals on the major chains, we're seeing around 50 to 60,000 individuals voting and around 60% to 80% of stake voting on each of these governance proposals. We have an extremely active governance community that helps make changes to these chains and sort of provide checks and balances to the various folks. If you remember, and I know you do, Laura, back in the sort of 2015 era with the SegWit changes on Bitcoin, people wanted to increase the block space. And one of the proposed mechanisms to help sort of resolve disputes like this was on chain governance, you would vote directly on chain to sort of do this. And Cosmos is a bunch of bitcoiners. So of course we went and implemented that. And it is one of the things that makes Cosmos unique is this on chain governance, that does truly decentralized control of these systems. And when developers like me and Zucky or the ICF want to go make changes, we have to go to the community and convince them that those changes are a good idea or else they vote them down. Like what happened with Prop 69 on the Cosmos hub. There was a lot of folks who wanted to put Cosm WASM, which is a virtual machine, onto the Cosmos Hub that would allow us to deploy code in a different way, basically. But a lot of people opposed that and that got voted down and we don't have Cosmos on the Hub. So I think that you can go and look many governance proposals. I think you did some reporting on the Juno Whale issue and that is one of the things that sort of makes Cosmos unique.

text: Yeah, basically. So then I wanted to ask also about liquid staking which you guys will be introducing. Talk a little bit about what benefits you expect that will bring to Cosmos what problems it solves.
speaker: A

text: So myself and the Occlusion team, so like me, Christy, Tony and Chella have all have been working on this project, which is change the Cosmos default staking module. So again, Cosmos SDK comes with an implementation of proof of stake. One of the things that we've long believed is that you cannot stop liquid staking. Liquid staking is just part of staking. You could fight it or you could embrace it, but you cannot stop it. And so we've seen a number of liquid staking projects emerge in the Cosmos ecosystem and the Stride quicksilver lido is coming to the Cosmos ecosystem. There are persistence many more and so we have this very robust marketplace of different liquid staking providers. But one of the things that's really annoying about them all is that you have to wait 21 days to move your atoms from the old legacy staking to the new liquid staking system. And this change that we are putting into the Cosmos staking module that the Occlusion team has built basically gets rid of that 21 days specifically for this use case that allows you to move to liquid staking without having wait this 21 days. And so we think that will accelerate the adoption of liquid staking across the ecosystem. And our dream is kind of to kind of move to this world of 100% atom staked essentially that these liquid staked atoms become the currency of account in the atom economy that essentially all atoms are staked and that is the prime. Again, we view it as taking a couple of few years for doing this. This vision allows us to get to the point where to make that very low new issuance that we're trying to go to sustainable because the issuance needed to be adaptive in the past because your atoms could be either on securing the Cosmos Hub or in an osmosis liquidity pool. They could either be like securing the Cosmos Hub or collateralizing. A stablecoin liquid staking allows you to do both. And by actually gradually reducing the issuance, we're actually, basically incentivizing we're incentivizing a world in which the most atom holders, in order to earn yield, actually have to go out into the economy and actually use all the stuff.

text: Yeah. And then ultimately the value of atom would rise because there would be so much more stake.
